[paragraph].74. I have purposely avoided all mention of the <u>Beroidæ</u> in
the course of the present paper although they have many
remarkable resemblances to the animals of which it treats -
Still such observations as I have been enabled to make upon
them have led me to the belief that they do not so much
form a part of the present group as a link between it and
the Anthozoic Polypes - But I hope to return to this point
upon some future occasion - 

Sydney April 24 1848
***Since the above was writte I have had the opportunity
(by the kindess of W<sup>m</sup> MacLeay Eqr to whose advice I
am much indebted) of reading M. Dujardin's "Memoir
sur le develppement des Meduses et des Polypes Hydraires" 
contained in the annales des Sciences Naturalles for Nov<sup>r</sup> 1845
This author has, as it appears to me, been misled by 
the great analogy between the structure of a <u>Medusa</u> & <sup>that of</sup> the
generative organ of a a <u>Corniform Pol</u>ype - into taking
the detached organ of the <u>Polype</u> for a real <u>Medusa</u>
He does not hesitate to say that the Claviform 
Polypes are "only a first stage of development of the
Acelephæ" - He hints that each clavate <u>Polype</u> has its corresponding <u>Acelephe</u> and he does not hesitate to give the latter distinct names as 
independent genera (<u>Sthenyo</u> <u>Cladonema</u>)
